explanatory comments/crosstagging: The peacock has an important place in Hinduism. The national epic, the Ramayana, related that when the gods transformed themselves to animal forms in order to escape the demon Ravana. Indra, the god of thunder and war, became a peacock. In recompense the bird was endowed with a thousand eyes in its feathers, the capacity to rejoice when the rains came and the power to kill enemies. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Among Hindus and Moslems peacock feathers are believed to ward off evil, especially evil spirits. Umbrellas of plumes were carried by persons associated with royalty and one was held over the pope on important occasions. In India the mere sight of the bird is believed to bring good luck and to bestow peace of mind. (gs)
